SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: The graph shows the speed of a rolling ball over time. In the graph, t₁ and t₂ represent two times during the ball's motion.
problems/MA22HSP/media/1a.jpg
Which of the following setups would cause the ball to roll with the motion shown in the graph?

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations of Newton's law of gravitation and Coulomb's law to both qualitatively and quantitatively describe and predict the effects of gravitational and electrostatic forces between objects.
Content: The diagram shows two sets of charges.
problems/MA22HSP/media/2a.jpg
Which of the following describes the electric force between the charges?

A.Choice: Set A has a larger force, which is attractive.

B.Choice: Set A has a larger force, which is repulsive.

C.Choice: Set B has a larger force, which is attractive.

D.Choice: Set B has a larger force, which is repulsive.

SubTopics: Evaluate simple series and parallel circuits to predict changes to voltage, current, or resistance when simple changes are made to a circuit.
Content: A simple circuit is shown.
problems/MA22HSP/media/3a.jpg
Which of the following would reduce the total current in the circuit by half?

A.Choice: adding a 5 Ω resistor in parallel

B.Choice: adding a 10 Ω light bulb in series

C.Choice: replacing the 20 V battery with a 10 V battery

D.Choice: replacing the 20 V battery with a 40 V battery

SubTopics: Analyze data to support the claim that Newton's second law of motion is a mathematical model describing change in motion (the acceleration) of objects when acted on by a net force.
Content: The graph shows how the downward speed of a skydiver changes from the moment the skydiver jumps out of an airplane to just before the skydiver's parachute opens.
problems/MA22HSP/media/4a.jpg
Based on the graph, which diagram represents the forces acting on the skydiver at 30 s?

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to show that the total momentum of a system of interacting objects is conserved when there is no net force on the system.
Content: A 5.0 kg object is accelerated from rest by a force of 20 N to a final velocity of 5.0 m/s. What is the final momentum of the object?

SubTopics: Develop and use a model of magnetic or electric fields to illustrate the forces and changes in energy between two magnetically or electrically charged objects changing relative position in a magnetic or electric field, respectively.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS THREE PARTS.
Two charged objects, X and Y, are separated by a distance, d, as shown.
problems/MA22HSP/media/6a.jpg
Object Y is released so that it is free to move.
Which of the following describes the energy of object Y just before it is released?

A.Choice: Object Y has kinetic energy as a result of object X's electric field.

B.Choice: Object Y has potential energy as a result of object X's electric field.

C.Choice: Object Y has kinetic energy as a result of object X's relative motion.

D.Choice: Object Y has potential energy as a result of object X's relative motion.

Content: Which of the following describes the energy and movement of object Y after it is released?

A.Choice: Object Y's energy is converted into kinetic energy as it moves toward object X.

B.Choice: Object Y's energy is converted into potential energy as it moves toward object X.

C.Choice: Object Y's energy is converted into kinetic energy as it moves away from object X.

D.Choice: Object Y's energy is converted into potential energy as it moves away from object X.

Content: Which of the following diagrams represents the electric field lines around the two objects?

SubTopics: Provide evidence that an electric current can produce a magnetic field and that a changing magnetic field can produce an electric current.
Content: During an investigation, a student placed a compass above a wire in a circuit, as shown in the diagram.
problems/MA22HSP/media/7a.jpg
The student recorded the position of the compass needle when the switch was open and when it was closed.
Which of the following claims is supported by evidence produced in this investigation?

A.Choice: An electric current produces a magnetic field.

B.Choice: A magnetic field produces an electric current.

C.Choice: An electric current flows from a negative to a positive terminal.

D.Choice: A magnetic field extends from the north pole of a magnet to its south pole.

SubTopics: Design and evaluate a device that works within given constraints to convert one form of energy into another form of energy.
Content: A launcher was made with a spring held in place inside a tube. The diagrams show the launcher before and after energy was transferred from the spring to a block. Initially the block was held at rest, and the compressed spring stored 0.45 J of elastic potential energy.
problems/MA22HSP/media/8a.jpg
problems/MA22HSP/media/8b.jpg
After the spring was released, the block exited the launcher with 0.3 J of kinetic energy. What was the percent efficiency of the launcher?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Communicate technical information about how some technological devices use the principles of wave behavior and wave interactions with matter to transmit and capture information and energy.
Content: The diagram represents a light ray and its path as it travels from air to glass.
problems/MA22HSP/media/9a.jpg
Which of the following best describes the angle of refraction as the light ray moves from air to glass?

A.Choice: The angle of refraction is equal to the angle of incidence because the speed of light increases.

B.Choice: The angle of refraction is smaller than the angle of incidence because the speed of light increases.

C.Choice: The angle of refraction is smaller than the angle of incidence because the speed of light decreases.

D.Choice: The angle of refraction is equal to the angle of incidence because the speed of light stays the same.

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: Ultraviolet radiation from the Sun can cause sunburn, but sitting in a classroom under visible light will not. This is because ultraviolet radiation particles have more energy than visible light particles.
Which of the following explains why ultraviolet radiation particles have more energy than visible light particles?

A.Choice: Ultraviolet radiation particles have a greater mass.

B.Choice: Ultraviolet radiation particles have a greater velocity.

C.Choice: Ultraviolet radiation particles have a greater frequency.

D.Choice: Ultraviolet radiation particles have a greater wavelength.

SubTopics: Evaluate simple series and parallel circuits to predict changes to voltage, current, or resistance when simple changes are made to a circuit.
Content: The diagram shows a series circuit containing a battery and three resistors.
problems/MA22HSP/media/11a.jpg
What is the current in the circuit?

SubTopics: Use algebraic expressions and the principle of energy conservation to calculate the change in energy of one component of a system when the change in energy of the other component(s) of the system, as well as the total energy of the system including any energy entering or leaving the system, is known. Identify any transformations from one form of energy to another, including thermal, kinetic, gravitational, magnetic, or electrical energy, in the system.
Content: Which of the following best describes what happened to the energy of the hanging object as it moved closer to the floor?

A.Choice: The kinetic energy of the hanging object increased as its thermal energy decreased.

B.Choice: The kinetic energy of the hanging object decreased as its gravitational potential energy increased.

C.Choice: The gravitational potential energy of the hanging object decreased as its kinetic energy increased.

D.Choice: The gravitational potential energy of the hanging object increased as its thermal energy increased.

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: Which pair of diagrams best compares the tension force acting on the block at position Y in trial 1 with the tension force acting on the block at position Y in trial 5?

SubTopics: Use algebraic expressions and the principle of energy conservation to calculate the change in energy of one component of a system when the change in energy of the other component(s) of the system, as well as the total energy of the system including any energy entering or leaving the system, is known. Identify any transformations from one form of energy to another, including thermal, kinetic, gravitational, magnetic, or electrical energy, in the system.
Content: In trial 5, the block traveled from position X to position Y in 0.69 s and had a velocity of 2.33 m/s at position Y. What was the kinetic energy of the block at position Y?

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Which free-body force diagram best represents the forces that acted on the block as it accelerated across the table?
As the block accelerated across the table, the speed of the block

SubTopics: Analyze data to support the claim that Newton's second law of motion is a mathematical model describing change in motion (the acceleration) of objects when acted on by a net force.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS THREE PARTS.

For a new trial, the students used the same setup, but the hanging object was 0.6 kg, and they collected different data. During the trial, the students recorded the time it took the block to travel from position X to position Y and the change in velocity of the block between those positions. The table shows the data.
problems/MA22HSP/media/16a.jpg
Calculate the average acceleration (to the nearest hundredth) of the system during the new trial. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
The original distance between positions X and Y was 0.8 m. The students reduced the distance to 0.4 m. The students released the block from rest, allowing it to move the 0.4 m.
Determine whether the velocity of the block at position Y was greater than, less than, or equal to 2.65 m/s. Explain your reasoning.
Describe one way the students could decrease the acceleration of the system without changing the mass of the hanging object. Explain your reasoning.

SubTopics: Apply scientific principles of motion and momentum to design, evaluate, and refine a device that minimizes the force on a macroscopic object during a collision.
Content: The velocity of a 75 kg skier increases from 8 m/s to 12 m/s. What is the change in momentum of the skier?

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations of Newton's law of gravitation and Coulomb's law to both qualitatively and quantitatively describe and predict the effects of gravitational and electrostatic forces between objects.
Content: The diagram shows a negatively charged sphere suspended a distance, d, above another negatively charged sphere in a glass tube.
problems/MA22HSP/media/18a.jpg
Which of the following would increase the distance, d, the most?

A.Choice: adding more negative charges to both spheres

B.Choice: removing some negative charges from both spheres

C.Choice: adding more negative charges to one sphere and making the other sphere neutral

D.Choice: removing some negative charges from one sphere and making the other sphere neutral

SubTopics: Analyze data to support the claim that Newton's second law of motion is a mathematical model describing change in motion (the acceleration) of objects when acted on by a net force.
Content: Which graph represents the motion of an object that has zero net force acting on it?

SubTopics: Use algebraic expressions and the principle of energy conservation to calculate the change in energy of one component of a system when the change in energy of the other component(s) of the system, as well as the total energy of the system including any energy entering or leaving the system, is known. Identify any transformations from one form of energy to another, including thermal, kinetic, gravitational, magnetic, or electrical energy, in the system.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS FOUR PARTS.

A diagram of a roller coaster track at an amusement park is shown. The location where passengers get into a car to ride along the track is labeled “Start.” Four additional points along the track are labeled W, X, Y, and Z.
problems/MA22HSP/media/20a.jpg

For one ride, a car and its passengers had a total mass of 4500 kg. The car was pulled with a motor from the starting point to point W. The car was held at rest at point W until it was released. The car then moved along the track to point Z with negligible friction.
Identify the point on the roller coaster track where the car and its passengers had the greatest amount of gravitational potential energy.
Calculate the amount of gravitational potential energy the car and its passengers had at the point you identified in Part A. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.

Compare (greater than, less than, or equal to) the amount of kinetic energy of the car and its passengers at point Y to the amount of kinetic energy of the car and its passengers at point Z. Explain your reasoning.
Identify the height, in meters, at which the kinetic energy of the car and its passengers was equal to the gravitational potential energy of the car and its passengers. Explain your reasoning.

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS THREE PARTS.
A person at a baseball game is seated 200 m away from a batter. The person sees the batter hit a ball, and then hears the sound of the ball being hit 0.58 s later.
Calculate the speed (to the nearest whole) of the sound wave created when the bat hits the ball. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
Besides the difference in speed of the two types of waves, describe TWO additional differences between the visible light waves and the sound waves produced when the ball is hit.
The game is also broadcast over the radio for people who cannot attend the game. Radio waves carry the broadcast signal.
One way that visible light waves differ from radio waves is that they can be seen by humans, while radio waves cannot. Describe a second difference between the two types of waves.

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: The graph represents the motion of a car on a straight highway.
problems/MA22HSP/media/22a.jpg
What distance did the car travel from 4 s to 8 s?

SubTopics: Analyze data to support the claim that Newton's second law of motion is a mathematical model describing change in motion (the acceleration) of objects when acted on by a net force.
Content: A box is at rest on a floor. Then a student drags the box across the floor. The diagram shows the horizontal forces acting on the box as it is being dragged.
problems/MA22HSP/media/23a.jpg
Based on Newton's second law, what is the velocity of the box 1 s after the student starts dragging it?

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to show that the total momentum of a system of interacting objects is conserved when there is no net force on the system.
Content: Two rubber balls roll along a straight track toward each other at the same speed. The balls are the same size but have different masses. The two balls collide.
Which of the following best describes how the total momentum of the rubber balls is affected by the collision?

A.Choice: The total momentum stays the same, because the total momentum is conserved.

B.Choice: The total momentum is doubled, because each ball gains the other ball's momentum.

C.Choice: The total momentum is reduced by half, because each ball loses half of its momentum.

D.Choice: The total momentum becomes zero, because the momentum of each ball is equal and opposite.

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
A hiker walked on a path.
The graph shows the position of the hiker versus time. The hiker started at position S. Four additional points on the graph are labeled H, I, J, and K.
problems/MA22HSP/media/25a.jpg
At which point was the hiker farthest from the starting position?
The graph shows the hiker's position during four time intervals, W, X, Y, and Z.
problems/MA22HSP/media/25b.jpg
During which time interval was the speed of the hiker the greatest?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: A wave travels at 10 m/s with a wavelength of 2 m. What is the frequency of this wave?

SubTopics: Develop a model to illustrate the energy released or absorbed during the processes of fission, fusion, and radioactive decay.
Content: A type of radioactive decay is represented by the diagram.
problems/MA22HSP/media/27a.jpg
Which of the following best describes what happens to the original nucleus during the decay process?

A.Choice: The original nucleus absorbs energy and its mass increases.

B.Choice: The original nucleus releases energy and its mass increases.

C.Choice: The original nucleus absorbs energy and its mass decreases.

D.Choice: The original nucleus releases energy and its mass decreases.

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Communicate technical information about how some technological devices use the principles of wave behavior and wave interactions with matter to transmit and capture information and energy.
Content: The diagram shows two wave pulses moving toward each other.
problems/MA22HSP/media/28a.jpg
Which diagram shows the shape of the wave when the pulses directly overlap?

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations of Newton's law of gravitation and Coulomb's law to both qualitatively and quantitatively describe and predict the effects of gravitational and electrostatic forces between objects.
Content: The table provides information about four pairs of objects.
problems/MA22HSP/media/29a.jpg
Which pair of objects has the GREATEST gravitational attraction?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: The graph shows the speed of sound at different temperatures in three media: X, Y, and Z.
problems/MA22HSP/media/30a.jpg
The three media are air (a gas), silver (a solid), and water (a liquid). Based on the graph, each medium is represented by which letter?

A.Choice:
X: water

Y: silver

Z: air

B.Choice:
X: silver

Y: water

Z: air

C.Choice:
X: air

Y: silver

Z: water

D.Choice:
X: water

Y: air

Z: silver

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to show that the total momentum of a system of interacting objects is conserved when there is no net force on the system.
Content: Two steel spheres, A and B, each have a mass of 0.54 kg. Each sphere is moving to the right at a different speed, as shown.
problems/MA22HSP/media/31a.jpg
Sphere A collides with sphere B. After the collision, sphere A slows, but both spheres continue to move to the right.
Which of the following diagrams shows the velocity of each sphere after the collision?

SubTopics: Apply scientific principles of motion and momentum to design, evaluate, and refine a device that minimizes the force on a macroscopic object during a collision.
Content: An airbag helps prevent injuries to the driver of a car when the car comes to a sudden stop. Which of the following best describes how the airbag helps prevent injuries to the driver?

A.Choice: The airbag reduces the initial momentum of the driver, safely slowing the driver to a stop.

B.Choice: The airbag causes the driver to come to a stop over a larger time interval, reducing the force felt by the driver.

C.Choice: The airbag causes the driver to come to a stop over a smaller time interval, increasing the momentum of the driver.

D.Choice: The airbag exerts a greater force on the driver than the driver exerts on the airbag, safely slowing the driver to a stop.

SubTopics: Provide evidence that when two objects of different temperature are in thermal contact within a closed system, the transfer of thermal energy from higher-temperature objects to lower-temperature objects results in thermal equilibrium, or a more uniform energy distribution among the objects and that temperature changes necessary to achieve thermal equilibrium depend on the specific heat values of the two substances.
Content: The data from investigation 1 are represented in the graph. Four points on the graph are labeled W, X, Y, and Z.
problems/MA22HSP/media/33a.jpg
At which point did container 1 and container 2 first reach thermal equilibrium?

SubTopics: Provide evidence that when two objects of different temperature are in thermal contact within a closed system, the transfer of thermal energy from higher-temperature objects to lower-temperature objects results in thermal equilibrium, or a more uniform energy distribution among the objects and that temperature changes necessary to achieve thermal equilibrium depend on the specific heat values of the two substances.
Content: Before beginning investigation 1, the student predicted that the direction of thermal energy transfer would be from container 1 to container 2.
Which of the following observations best supports the student's prediction?

A.Choice: The containers are good thermal insulators.

B.Choice: The U-shaped piece of metal is a good thermal conductor.

C.Choice: The water in container 1 is in thermal contact with the water in container 2.

D.Choice: The water in container 1 is at a higher temperature than the water in container 2.

SubTopics: Provide evidence that when two objects of different temperature are in thermal contact within a closed system, the transfer of thermal energy from higher-temperature objects to lower-temperature objects results in thermal equilibrium, or a more uniform energy distribution among the objects and that temperature changes necessary to achieve thermal equilibrium depend on the specific heat values of the two substances.
Content: In investigation 2, liquid Z had an initial temperature of 25°C before 54,316 J of thermal energy was added. What was the final temperature of liquid Z?

SubTopics: Provide evidence that when two objects of different temperature are in thermal contact within a closed system, the transfer of thermal energy from higher-temperature objects to lower-temperature objects results in thermal equilibrium, or a more uniform energy distribution among the objects and that temperature changes necessary to achieve thermal equilibrium depend on the specific heat values of the two substances.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
During the first 50 s of investigation 2, the temperature of 200 g of liquid W changed from 25°C to 31°C. How much thermal energy was transferred to liquid W in the first 50 s of investigation 2?
The student repeated investigation 2 with 400 g of liquid W instead of 200 g. The student used the same heat source and heated liquid W for the same amount of time.
How were the results of the investigation different when 400 g of liquid W were used instead of 200 g?

A.Choice: The change in temperature of liquid W was greater.

B.Choice: The change in temperature of liquid W was smaller.

C.Choice: The amount of thermal energy transferred to liquid W was greater.

D.Choice: The amount of thermal energy transferred to liquid W was smaller.

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to illustrate that energy at the macroscopic scale can be accounted for as either motions of particles and objects or energy stored in fields.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS THREE PARTS.
The student analyzed the transfer of thermal energy that took place during investigation 1.
Identify whether the average molecular motion of the water molecules in EACH of container 1 AND container 2 increased, decreased, or remained the same during the first 100 s of investigation 1.
The student claimed that energy was conserved in the system during the transfer of thermal energy in investigation 1.
Describe how the student could use the data in Table 1 to support the claim.
Eventually thermal equilibrium was reached in investigation 1.
Compare the average molecular motion of the water molecules in both container 1 and container 2 after thermal equilibrium was reached. Explain your reasoning.

SubTopics: Provide evidence that an electric current can produce a magnetic field and that a changing magnetic field can produce an electric current.
Content: The diagram shows a simple circuit. A location near the circuit is labeled X.
problems/MA22HSP/media/38a.jpg
Which of the following explains whether there is a magnetic field at point X?

A.Choice: There is no magnetic field at point X because wires are not magnets.

B.Choice: There is no magnetic field at point X because it is too far from the battery.

C.Choice: There is a magnetic field at point X because current flows through the wire.

D.Choice: There is a magnetic field at point X because the light has magnetic properties.

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: Elephants use sound for communication. The table shows the average frequencies of sound waves produced by adult elephants and their young.
problems/MA22HSP/media/39a.jpg
What additional information is needed to determine the wavelengths of the sounds produced by the elephants?

A.Choice: the speed of the sound waves

B.Choice: the period of the sound waves

C.Choice: the energy the sound waves carry

D.Choice: the distance the sound waves travel

SubTopics: Evaluate simple series and parallel circuits to predict changes to voltage, current, or resistance when simple changes are made to a circuit.
Content: The circuit shown has a current of 0.6 A.
problems/MA22HSP/media/40a.jpg
What is the voltage of the battery?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Communicate technical information about how some technological devices use the principles of wave behavior and wave interactions with matter to transmit and capture information and energy.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.

A student listening to music uses noise-canceling headphones to reduce outside noise. The headphones create an inverted sound wave that interacts with the outside noise. The diagram represents how the headphones work.
problems/MA22HSP/media/41a.jpg
Which wave behavior is used by the noise-canceling headphones to reduce outside noise for the student?

The student then uses the noise-canceling headphones in a location where the outside noise is louder and has a higher pitch. How would the noise-canceling wave produced by the headphones need to change for the headphones to be equally effective when the outside noise is louder and has a higher pitch?

A.Choice: The wave's velocity and wavelength would need to increase.

B.Choice: The wave's velocity and wavelength would need to decrease.

C.Choice: The wave's frequency and amplitude would need to increase.

D.Choice: The wave's frequency and amplitude would need to decrease.

SubTopics: Evaluate simple series and parallel circuits to predict changes to voltage, current, or resistance when simple changes are made to a circuit.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS THREE PARTS.
The diagram shows a circuit with a 12 V battery, three resistors, and component K.
problems/MA22HSP/media/42a.jpg
Identify component K AND explain its main function.
Component K is replaced with a piece of wire.
Calculate the total resistance of the circuit. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
Is the amount of current flowing through R₁ the same as the amount of current flowing through R₂? Explain your reasoning.
Calculate the voltage drop across R1. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
